title: Live updates: Israel and Hamas agree to ceasefire deal, including hostage release, Biden says
description: The first phase of the agreement brokered by the United States, Qatar and Egypt will halt, for now, a 15-month war that changed the Middle East.
author: John Hudson, Frances Vinall, Abbie Cheeseman, Heba Farouk Mahfouz , Sammy Westfall, Karen DeYoung, Michael Birnbaum
byline: John Hudson, Frances Vinall, Abbie Cheeseman, Heba Farouk Mahfouz, Sammy Westfall, Karen DeYoung, Michael Birnbaum, María Luisa Paúl, Miriam Berger, Adam Taylor, Susannah George, Mohamad El Chamaa, Gerry Shih, Bryan Pietsch, Leo Sands, Lior Soroka, Cleve R. Wootson Jr., Kareem Fahim, Victoria Bisset, Júlia Ledur, Leslie Shapiro, Ishaan Tharoor, Claire Parker
excerpt: The first phase of the agreement brokered by the United States, Qatar and Egypt will halt, for now, a 15-month war that changed the Middle East.
text: A hostage and ceasefire deal between Hamas and Israel was reached Wednesday, following more than 15 months of extraordinary bloodshed and violence in Gaza, President Joe Biden said Wednesday. Implementation of the agreement is set to start Sunday, according to Qatar’s Prime Minister. The agreement, which requires ratification by a vote of Israel’s cabinet, follows an intense period of meetings and calls over the past several days, including by Biden to the leaders of Israel and mediating partners Qatar and Egypt. Steve Witkoff, President-elect Donald Trump’s special envoy to the Middle East, has also played an instrumental role, meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over the weekend to express Trump’s interest in attaining a deal before his inauguration on Monday.Live coverage contributors 23Return to menuFormer president Barack Obama welcomed the ceasefire deal, calling it “good news” for both the Israeli and Palestinian civilians who’ve been caught in the crossfire of war.While the agreement can’t undo the pain of loss or resolve the broader Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Obama wrote on X, “it will put a stop to the bloodshed, allow people to return to their homes, and get much-needed aid to more than a million desperate, hungry people.”Return to menuIsraeli airstrikes on Wednesday — coming after the announcement of a ceasefire deal — killed at least 19 people across Gaza, according to the enclave’s Civil Defense service. The rescue agency said in a statement that many of the strikes targeted residential areas.Israel’s former defense minister praises ceasefire deal, thanks U.S.Return to menuIsrael’s former defense minister Yoav Gallant on Wednesday welcomed the ceasefire and hostage release deal, saying that “national and security considerations prevailed over political interest” in a post on X.“Tonight, I salute those who paid the price to make this agreement possible — our courageous troops and service-members,” Gallant said, “the wounded and the fallen heroes who fought fiercely against a brutal enemy and created the conditions necessary to bring our people home.”Return to menuDuring a Wednesday briefing, State Department spokesman Matthew Miller said the United States is aiming for over 500 trucks of aid to reach Gaza daily. He said the ceasefire offers “a real solution” to logistical challenges — particularly in ensuring aid is delivered beyond Gaza’s gates.The new deal, Miller added, “unlocks the potential to massively surge humanitarian assistance.”Return to menuPrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke Wednesday with President Joe Biden and President-elect Donald Trump.Netanyahu thanked Trump for “helping Israel bring an end to the suffering of dozens of hostages and their families," in a tweet from the Israeli Prime Minister’s Office. He also “commended” the U.S. President-elect for his comments that the United States would help Israel ensure that Gaza will “never be a haven for terrorism.” Netanyahu said he and Trump agreed to meet in Washington some time in the near future.Netanyahu also “spoke with US President Joe Biden and thanked him as well for his assistance in advancing the hostages deal," the prime minister’s office said.A senior Biden administration official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity under rules set by the White House, described the call with Biden as “very warm.”In photos: Palestinians in Gaza celebrate news of a ceasefireReturn to menuTwo American hostages in Gaza to be released among initial group of 33Return to menuTwo American hostages in Gaza, Keith Siegel and Sagui Dekel-Chen, will be part of the initial group of 33 captives to be released in the first phase of Wednesday’s ceasefire deal, said a senior Biden administration official who spoke on the condition of anonymity under rules set by the White House.Return to menuPhilippe Lazzarini, who leads the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, welcomed the ceasefire in Gaza, calling it “much needed respite” after 15 months of conflict.“What’s needed is rapid, unhindered & uninterrupted humanitarian access and supplies to respond to the tremendous suffering caused by this war,” he wrote on X.Last year, Israel passed twin bills banning UNRWA’s work in its territory and prohibiting contact between its staff and government officials.Rights groups call for surge of aid into Gaza, ask all sides to respect agreementReturn to menuHuman rights groups welcomed the ceasefire and hostage release deal after 465 days of conflict in Gaza, but warned that it is only the first step.“Catastrophe persists,” said leading Israeli human rights watchdog B’Tselem in its statement welcoming the deal.U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk said that the ceasefire comes with the promise of “huge relief after so much unbearable pain and misery over the past 15 months.”Return to menuMouin Rabbani, a nonresident fellow at Qatar’s Center for Conflict and Humanitarian Studies, said that while Hamas has been cut down as a fighting and governing force in Gaza, the militant group is able to spin its survival, and the deal, as a win. “Often in these cases, when you’re looking at insurgent movements who are up against much more powerful states and conventional armies, surviving is considered a political victory,” he told The Post.In photos: Scenes in Israel as people react to ceasefire dealReturn to menuCeasefire will mark first reprieve from violence in Gaza since November 2023Return to menuThe ceasefire announced Wednesday will be the first reprieve from violence that Gaza residents have had since November 2023, more than 400 days ago, when Israel and Hamas agreed to a short pause in the fighting that lasted seven days after being extended twice.Who is Steve Witkoff, the Trump envoy who played a role in ceasefire talks?Return to menuThough part of the incoming administration, Steve Witkoff, President-elect Donald Trump’s designated Middle East special envoy, has already played a role in the ceasefire talks between Israel and Hamas. Witkoff has visited Doha, Qatar, at various points since negotiations intensified last month, and he met with leaders including Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over the weekend.Displaced Gazans hope to return home after news of ceasefire Return to menuGazans expressed hope Jan. 15 as Israel and Hamas agreed to a ceasefire that life could return to how it was before the war. (Video: Reuters)Displaced Gazans are hopeful that the news of a ceasefire could allow them to return home, but some said that even if the fighting ends, the scale of loss has been immense.“Everything has been destroyed. Nothing in Gaza is fit for life,” said Mohammed al-Masra, a pharmacist interviewed by Reuters on Wednesday.“A year or two of our lives have been wasted for nothing,” Hanan Bargouth, a displaced woman from Gaza City, told the news agency from Khan Younis.Qatar’s prime minister credits Biden and Trump for helping secure ceasefireReturn to menuQatar’s prime minister announced that a ceasefire deal agreed to by Israel and Hamas will go into effect Sunday, after some “internal” implementation measures being determined in Israel.The ceasefire will free dozens of hostages and pause the conflict in Gaza after more than 15 months of devastating war.Negotiating teams and mediators have worked for months to hammer out a deal in Doha, where talks were deadlocked for most of last year.Ceasefire deal remains to be approved by Israel’s governmentReturn to menuBefore the deal can be formally implemented, it needs to be approved Thursday morning by Netanyahu’s 11-member inner cabinet and then the 34 ministers of his coalition government.How the ceasefire is set to work, according to Biden Return to menuPresident Joe Biden outlined the structure of the ceasefire and hostage-release agreement in remarks on Wednesday. The plan has three phases, he said, which will ideally culminate in the release of all the hostages — dead and alive — and the rebuilding of the Gaza Strip.Here’s how the agreement will work, according to Biden.Here’s what we know about the Israel-Hamas ceasefire dealReturn to menuThe first phase would involve 33 living hostages being released over a 42-day ceasefire, in exchange for the release of Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, according to U.S. officials.An Israeli official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss negotiations, said Tuesday that the captives released in the first stage would be children, women, injured people and those 50 and older.The Israeli official said that in a second stage, other remaining hostages and Israeli soldiers being held captive by Hamas would be released. According to The Washington Post’s tracker, Israel estimates there are 60 living hostages remaining in Gaza.Israel would agree to allow hundreds of thousands of Palestinian civilians who have fled Israel’s bombardment in the south of Gaza to return to their homes in the north as long as unspecified security measures are in place.The Israeli official said Tuesday that Israel intends to maintain a buffer zone in Gaza.The extent of the Israeli military’s continued presence in the Netzarim Corridor, an east-west passage dividing the enclave, remained unclear.The existing plan is for three hostages to be the first released, a process that will take at least 48 to 72 hours and maybe longer to arrange even after a deal is agreed, said a senior U.S. official Wednesday, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss the sensitive negotiations.Other hostages in the group of 33 to be released during the initial six-week ceasefire are to be released in groups — the size and composition of which are among the final details still being worked out, the senior U.S. official said.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuIsrael’s President Isaac Herzog called on cabinet members and government ministers to approve Wednesday’s deal. “This is the right, important, and necessary move. There is no greater moral obligation than bringing back our brothers and sisters.”Biden says ceasefire agreement same as plan he proposed last yearReturn to menuPresident Joe Biden said in a statement Wednesday that the ceasefire agreement was effectively the same as the plan he unveiled in May.“I laid out the precise contours of this plan on May 31, 2024, after which it was endorsed unanimously by the U.N. Security Council,” he said.Biden says he’s handing Trump ‘a real opportunity’ for a better Middle EastReturn to menuPresident Joe Biden said in his first public remarks after Wednesday’s ceasefire agreement that the deal was “developed and negotiated” by his administration but that it will be implemented by President-elect Donald Trump’s administration.Over the past few days, he said, “we’ve been speaking as one team.” He said he was “handing off” to the Trump administration “a real opportunity for a brighter future for the Middle East. I hope they will take it.”‘Is it real? Have they signed?’: Palestinians in Gaza celebrate ceasefire newsReturn to menuIn Gaza, celebrations rang out as Palestinians heard the news that a ceasefire agreement was reached.Mohamed Abualkas, 32, said he hopes that the ceasefire really happens “so that I could sleep for two days straight without fear.”It broke his heart to watch the celebrations and happiness of all those living in tents around him, he said: “What do we have left?”Trump claims credit for ceasefire agreementReturn to menuPresident-elect Donald Trump swiftly claimed credit Wednesday for the ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas after news of it emerged.Biden administration officials, while crediting Trump’s Middle East envoy Steve Witkoff’s contribution during the last phase of the negotiations as crucial to their success, have been careful to say that he has not directly participated in the negotiations.Return to menuImplementation of the ceasefire agreement is set to start Sunday, Qatari Prime Minister Abdulrahman bin Jassim Al Thani said Wednesday in Doha. He added that some details remain to be ironed out.“The parties said that a number of days will be required to bring [the deal] into implementation and to be able to honor their obligations,” Al Thani said. “We hope that the coming days will not see any military operations.”Return to menuA statement by Gaza’s civil defense Wednesday evening called on people to refrain from firing celebratory gunfire into the air, for fear of injuring displaced people in tents and shelters.“We do not want to be saddened by more martyrs and injured,” the statement said.Return to menuThe families of American hostages held in Gaza said in a joint statement that they are “deeply grateful” for Wednesday’s agreement — while also noting that “the coming days and weeks will be just as painful for our families as the entirety of our loved ones’ horrific ordeals.”The families asked all parties to “stay committed to this agreement, every phase until it is fully implemented and everyone has been returned.”Return to menuMoments after news of the ceasefire deal emerged, the office of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu released a statement claiming credit for the final push — and warning of some remaining issues.“Due to the strong insistence of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Hamas folded on its last-minute demand to change the deployment of IDF forces in the Philadelphi Corridor,” his office said. “However, several items in the framework have yet to be finalized; we hope that the details will be finalized tonight.”Return to menuMiki Zohar, Israel’s minister of culture, called on government ministers to vote Thursday in favor of the deal — a step required to formalize it on the Israeli side.“Together with my colleagues, we will vote tomorrow at the government meeting on the deal led by Prime Minister Netanyahu with President Trump to secure the release of our brothers and sisters languishing in the hands of the despicable Hamas,” he said.Return to menuThere are still numerous open questions about how the ceasefire deal reached Wednesday will work, said Tamer Qarmout, a Gazan professor of public policy at the Doha Institute for Graduate Studies.“Who’s going to govern Gaza?” asked Qarmout. “How will reconstruction be carried out? Who’s going to commit resources and financial means for this reconstruction? Who will be the main actors to play on? What will be the Israeli factor? Will Israel cooperate, or will Israel introduce obstacles?”The “big missing element,” Qarmout said, is “a political settlement or a political proposal to end this conflict.”Return to menuIsraeli President Isaac Herzog met Wednesday with the president of the International Red Cross, Mirjana Spoljaric, and her team, who were in Israel to prepare for a transfer of the hostages under a ceasefire and hostage release deal.Herzog emphasized the “utmost importance and sensitivity of this mission,” according to the president’s office.Following a pattern established in a hostage release in late 2023, the International Committee of the Red Cross would likely escort the hostages from an agreed assembly point along a secured route, a senior U.S. official said earlier Wednesday, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss the sensitive negotiations.Return to menuYehuda Cohen, whose son, Nimrod Cohen, is held hostage in Gaza, said the deal “is just the beginning.” There is still a “long way [and fight] to go,” he told The Post on Wednesday as news of the ceasefire deal broke.Nimrod was captured by Hamas-led fighters from his military base in southern Israel on Oct. 7, 2023. As a soldier, he would probably be released as part of the second phase, according to an Israeli official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss a sensitive matter, but the exact details would be set during the first phase.Cohen said he supports a deal, but he and other hostage families are frustrated that only some hostages will be released at first; they are fearful for those who will initially remain behind.Ceasefire and hostage-release deal to halt Gaza war for now, after months of impasse Return to menuThe first phase of the deal calls for a 42-day ceasefire and the release of an initial 33 hostages followed by subsequent releases during that period. A second senior U.S. official, who spoke on the condition on anonymity for the same reason, said three hostages would be released within 48 to 72 hours of the agreement, along with a still-unknown number of Palestinian prisoners being held in Israeli jails and an increased flow of humanitarian aid into Gaza.Return to menuPresident Biden is expected to speak on the deal as soon as it announced in Qatar.Monitoring the status of hostages still in GazaReturn to menuThe cross-border attack that Hamas militants launched on Oct. 7, 2023, is regarded as the deadliest and most brutal attack in Israeli history. Palestinian militants shot, bombed and burned their way through Israeli towns, military posts and a music festival, killing and sometimes torturing 1,200 people — including more than 300 soldiers — and taking 251 more hostage, according to the Israeli government. We’re tracking what happened to each of them.This is an excerpt from a full story.A wounded Israeli soldier demands return of hostages, and war to go onReturn to menuTEL AVIV — Yuval Shalem, 49, joined protests in Tel Aviv demanding a hostage deal for the first time Tuesday, while wounded and in a wheelchair.He was badly injured Saturday in an explosion that killed four fellow Israeli soldiers on patrol in Beit Hanoun, in the northern Gaza Strip, while looking for a tunnel entrance, he said. Shalem came to the protest, he added, to demand “both” — the return of the hostages and the war to go on.Analysis: Trump moves the needle on a Gaza ceasefireReturn to menuIf a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas is clinched in the coming hours, the terms will likely be little different than what they would have been months ago. A number of living hostages in captivity in Gaza will be swapped for a number of Palestinian detainees in Israeli jails in a “first phase” of a truce. Hostilities will cease for a prescribed set of weeks, in the articulated hope that a later second phase of exchanges will happen and an extended peace will take root.This is an excerpt from a full story.Blinken presents postwar plan for Gaza: Unite with West Bank under reformed Palestinian AuthorityReturn to menuSecretary of State Antony Blinken presented a long-delayed plan for postwar Gaza on Tuesday that would unite the West Bank and Gaza under a reformed Palestinian Authority-led government.The plan would rely on the incoming Trump administration to carry it forward, reducing it to a Democratic proposal that can be readily dismissed or rewritten by a Republican White House.Both sides hammering out final details, former Egyptian official saysReturn to menuJERUSALEM — Negotiators in Doha were still hammering out the final details of a ceasefire in Gaza on Tuesday, as momentum and expectations build that a 15-month war may soon halt and Israeli hostages will be freed in exchange for Palestinian prisoners.Middle East conflict Israel and Hamas have agreed to a ceasefire deal — including the release of hostages — after more than 15 months of violence and tensions that have spilled over in the Middle East. Follow live updates on the ceasefire deal and the hostages remaining in Gaza.The Israel-Gaza war: On Oct. 7, 2023, Hamas militants launched an unprecedented cross-border attack on Israel, killing about 1,200 people and taking civilian hostages. Israel declared war on Hamas in response, launching a ground invasion that fueled the biggest displacement in the region since Israel’s creation in 1948. In July 2024, Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh was killed in an attack Hamas has blamed on Israel.Hezbollah: In late 2024, Israel and Lebanon’s Hezbollah agreed to a ceasefire deal, bringing a tenuous halt to more than a year of hostilities that included an Israeli invasion of southern Lebanon. Israel’s airstrikes into Lebanon had been intense and deadly, killing over 1,400 people including Hasan Nasrallah, Hezbollah’s longtime leader. The Israel-Lebanon border has a history of violence that dates back to Israel’s founding.Gaza crisis: In the Gaza Strip, Israel has waged one of this century’s most destructive wars, killing tens of thousands and plunging at least half of the population into “famine-like conditions.” For months, Israel has resisted pressure from Western allies to allow more humanitarian aid into the enclave.U.S. involvement: Despite tensions between Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and some U.S. politicians, including President Joe Biden, the United States supports Israel with weapons, funds aid packages, and has vetoed or abstained from the United Nations’ ceasefire resolutions.Live updates: Israel and Hamas agree to ceasefire deal, including hostage release, Biden saysIsrael and Hamas agree to Gaza ceasefire, raising hopes of a reprieveHere’s what we know about the Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal
html:
A hostage and ceasefire deal between Hamas and Israel was reached Wednesday, following more than 15 months of extraordinary bloodshed and violence in Gaza, President Joe Biden said Wednesday. Implementation of the agreement is set to start Sunday, according to Qatar’s Prime Minister. The agreement, which requires ratification by a vote of Israel’s cabinet, follows an intense period of meetings and calls over the past several days, including by Biden to the leaders of Israel and mediating partners Qatar and Egypt. Steve Witkoff, President-elect Donald Trump’s special envoy to the Middle East, has also played an instrumental role, meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over the weekend to express Trump’s interest in attaining a deal before his inauguration on Monday.

Live coverage contributors 23

  • Return to menu

    Former president Barack Obama welcomed the ceasefire deal, calling it “good news” for both the Israeli and Palestinian civilians who’ve been caught in the crossfire of war.

    While the agreement can’t undo the pain of loss or resolve the broader Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Obama wrote on X, “it will put a stop to the bloodshed, allow people to return to their homes, and get much-needed aid to more than a million desperate, hungry people.”

  • Return to menu

    Israeli airstrikes on Wednesday — coming after the announcement of a ceasefire deal — killed at least 19 people across Gaza, according to the enclave’s Civil Defense service. The rescue agency said in a statement that many of the strikes targeted residential areas.

  • Israel’s former defense minister praises ceasefire deal, thanks U.S.

    Return to menu

    Israel’s former defense minister Yoav Gallant on Wednesday welcomed the ceasefire and hostage release deal, saying that “national and security considerations prevailed over political interest” in a post on X.

    “Tonight, I salute those who paid the price to make this agreement possible — our courageous troops and service-members,” Gallant said, “the wounded and the fallen heroes who fought fiercely against a brutal enemy and created the conditions necessary to bring our people home.”

  • Return to menu

    During a Wednesday briefing, State Department spokesman Matthew Miller said the United States is aiming for over 500 trucks of aid to reach Gaza daily. He said the ceasefire offers “a real solution” to logistical challenges — particularly in ensuring aid is delivered beyond Gaza’s gates.

    The new deal, Miller added, “unlocks the potential to massively surge humanitarian assistance.”

  • Return to menu

    Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke Wednesday with President Joe Biden and President-elect Donald Trump.

    Netanyahu thanked Trump for “helping Israel bring an end to the suffering of dozens of hostages and their families," in a tweet from the Israeli Prime Minister’s Office. He also “commended” the U.S. President-elect for his comments that the United States would help Israel ensure that Gaza will “never be a haven for terrorism.” Netanyahu said he and Trump agreed to meet in Washington some time in the near future.

    Netanyahu also “spoke with US President Joe Biden and thanked him as well for his assistance in advancing the hostages deal," the prime minister’s office said.

    A senior Biden administration official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity under rules set by the White House, described the call with Biden as “very warm.”

  • In photos: Palestinians in Gaza celebrate news of a ceasefire

    Return to menu

  • Two American hostages in Gaza to be released among initial group of 33

    Return to menu

    Two American hostages in Gaza, Keith Siegel and Sagui Dekel-Chen, will be part of the initial group of 33 captives to be released in the first phase of Wednesday’s ceasefire deal, said a senior Biden administration official who spoke on the condition of anonymity under rules set by the White House.

  • Return to menu

    Philippe Lazzarini, who leads the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, welcomed the ceasefire in Gaza, calling it “much needed respite” after 15 months of conflict.

    “What’s needed is rapid, unhindered & uninterrupted humanitarian access and supplies to respond to the tremendous suffering caused by this war,” he wrote on X.

    Last year, Israel passed twin bills banning UNRWA’s work in its territory and prohibiting contact between its staff and government officials.

  • Rights groups call for surge of aid into Gaza, ask all sides to respect agreement

    Return to menu

    Human rights groups welcomed the ceasefire and hostage release deal after 465 days of conflict in Gaza, but warned that it is only the first step.

    “Catastrophe persists,” said leading Israeli human rights watchdog B’Tselem in its statement welcoming the deal.

    U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk said that the ceasefire comes with the promise of “huge relief after so much unbearable pain and misery over the past 15 months.”

  • Return to menu

    Mouin Rabbani, a nonresident fellow at Qatar’s Center for Conflict and Humanitarian Studies, said that while Hamas has been cut down as a fighting and governing force in Gaza, the militant group is able to spin its survival, and the deal, as a win. “Often in these cases, when you’re looking at insurgent movements who are up against much more powerful states and conventional armies, surviving is considered a political victory,” he told The Post.

  • In photos: Scenes in Israel as people react to ceasefire deal

    Return to menu

  • Ceasefire will mark first reprieve from violence in Gaza since November 2023

    Return to menu

    The ceasefire announced Wednesday will be the first reprieve from violence that Gaza residents have had since November 2023, more than 400 days ago, when Israel and Hamas agreed to a short pause in the fighting that lasted seven days after being extended twice.

  • Who is Steve Witkoff, the Trump envoy who played a role in ceasefire talks?

    Return to menu

    Though part of the incoming administration, Steve Witkoff, President-elect Donald Trump’s designated Middle East special envoy, has already played a role in the ceasefire talks between Israel and Hamas. Witkoff has visited Doha, Qatar, at various points since negotiations intensified last month, and he met with leaders including Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over the weekend.

  • Displaced Gazans hope to return home after news of ceasefire

    Return to menu

    Displaced Gazans are hopeful that the news of a ceasefire could allow them to return home, but some said that even if the fighting ends, the scale of loss has been immense.

    “Everything has been destroyed. Nothing in Gaza is fit for life,” said Mohammed al-Masra, a pharmacist interviewed by Reuters on Wednesday.

    “A year or two of our lives have been wasted for nothing,” Hanan Bargouth, a displaced woman from Gaza City, told the news agency from Khan Younis.

  • Qatar’s prime minister credits Biden and Trump for helping secure ceasefire

    Return to menu

    Qatar’s prime minister announced that a ceasefire deal agreed to by Israel and Hamas will go into effect Sunday, after some “internal” implementation measures being determined in Israel.

    The ceasefire will free dozens of hostages and pause the conflict in Gaza after more than 15 months of devastating war.

    Negotiating teams and mediators have worked for months to hammer out a deal in Doha, where talks were deadlocked for most of last year.

  • Ceasefire deal remains to be approved by Israel’s government

    Return to menu

    Before the deal can be formally implemented, it needs to be approved Thursday morning by Netanyahu’s 11-member inner cabinet and then the 34 ministers of his coalition government.

  • How the ceasefire is set to work, according to Biden

    Return to menu

    President Joe Biden outlined the structure of the ceasefire and hostage-release agreement in remarks on Wednesday. The plan has three phases, he said, which will ideally culminate in the release of all the hostages — dead and alive — and the rebuilding of the Gaza Strip.

    Here’s how the agreement will work, according to Biden.

  • Here’s what we know about the Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal

    Return to menu

    • The first phase would involve 33 living hostages being released over a 42-day ceasefire, in exchange for the release of Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, according to U.S. officials.
    • An Israeli official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss negotiations, said Tuesday that the captives released in the first stage would be children, women, injured people and those 50 and older.
    • The Israeli official said that in a second stage, other remaining hostages and Israeli soldiers being held captive by Hamas would be released. According to The Washington Post’s tracker, Israel estimates there are 60 living hostages remaining in Gaza.
    • Israel would agree to allow hundreds of thousands of Palestinian civilians who have fled Israel’s bombardment in the south of Gaza to return to their homes in the north as long as unspecified security measures are in place.
    • The Israeli official said Tuesday that Israel intends to maintain a buffer zone in Gaza.
    • The extent of the Israeli military’s continued presence in the Netzarim Corridor, an east-west passage dividing the enclave, remained unclear.
    • The existing plan is for three hostages to be the first released, a process that will take at least 48 to 72 hours and maybe longer to arrange even after a deal is agreed, said a senior U.S. official Wednesday, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss the sensitive negotiations.
    • Other hostages in the group of 33 to be released during the initial six-week ceasefire are to be released in groups — the size and composition of which are among the final details still being worked out, the senior U.S. official said.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Return to menu

    Israel’s President Isaac Herzog called on cabinet members and government ministers to approve Wednesday’s deal. “This is the right, important, and necessary move. There is no greater moral obligation than bringing back our brothers and sisters.”

  • Biden says ceasefire agreement same as plan he proposed last year

    Return to menu

    President Joe Biden said in a statement Wednesday that the ceasefire agreement was effectively the same as the plan he unveiled in May.

    “I laid out the precise contours of this plan on May 31, 2024, after which it was endorsed unanimously by the U.N. Security Council,” he said.

  • Biden says he’s handing Trump ‘a real opportunity’ for a better Middle East

    Return to menu

    President Joe Biden said in his first public remarks after Wednesday’s ceasefire agreement that the deal was “developed and negotiated” by his administration but that it will be implemented by President-elect Donald Trump’s administration.

    Over the past few days, he said, “we’ve been speaking as one team.” He said he was “handing off” to the Trump administration “a real opportunity for a brighter future for the Middle East. I hope they will take it.”

  • ‘Is it real? Have they signed?’: Palestinians in Gaza celebrate ceasefire news

    Return to menu

    In Gaza, celebrations rang out as Palestinians heard the news that a ceasefire agreement was reached.

    Mohamed Abualkas, 32, said he hopes that the ceasefire really happens “so that I could sleep for two days straight without fear.”

    It broke his heart to watch the celebrations and happiness of all those living in tents around him, he said: “What do we have left?”

  • Trump claims credit for ceasefire agreement

    Return to menu

    President-elect Donald Trump swiftly claimed credit Wednesday for the ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas after news of it emerged.

    Biden administration officials, while crediting Trump’s Middle East envoy Steve Witkoff’s contribution during the last phase of the negotiations as crucial to their success, have been careful to say that he has not directly participated in the negotiations.

  • Return to menu

    Implementation of the ceasefire agreement is set to start Sunday, Qatari Prime Minister Abdulrahman bin Jassim Al Thani said Wednesday in Doha. He added that some details remain to be ironed out.

    “The parties said that a number of days will be required to bring [the deal] into implementation and to be able to honor their obligations,” Al Thani said. “We hope that the coming days will not see any military operations.”

  • Return to menu

    A statement by Gaza’s civil defense Wednesday evening called on people to refrain from firing celebratory gunfire into the air, for fear of injuring displaced people in tents and shelters.

    “We do not want to be saddened by more martyrs and injured,” the statement said.

  • Return to menu

    The families of American hostages held in Gaza said in a joint statement that they are “deeply grateful” for Wednesday’s agreement — while also noting that “the coming days and weeks will be just as painful for our families as the entirety of our loved ones’ horrific ordeals.”

    The families asked all parties to “stay committed to this agreement, every phase until it is fully implemented and everyone has been returned.”

  • Return to menu

    Moments after news of the ceasefire deal emerged, the office of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu released a statement claiming credit for the final push — and warning of some remaining issues.

    “Due to the strong insistence of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Hamas folded on its last-minute demand to change the deployment of IDF forces in the Philadelphi Corridor,” his office said. “However, several items in the framework have yet to be finalized; we hope that the details will be finalized tonight.”

  • Return to menu

    Miki Zohar, Israel’s minister of culture, called on government ministers to vote Thursday in favor of the deal — a step required to formalize it on the Israeli side.

    “Together with my colleagues, we will vote tomorrow at the government meeting on the deal led by Prime Minister Netanyahu with President Trump to secure the release of our brothers and sisters languishing in the hands of the despicable Hamas,” he said.

  • Return to menu

    There are still numerous open questions about how the ceasefire deal reached Wednesday will work, said Tamer Qarmout, a Gazan professor of public policy at the Doha Institute for Graduate Studies.

    “Who’s going to govern Gaza?” asked Qarmout. “How will reconstruction be carried out? Who’s going to commit resources and financial means for this reconstruction? Who will be the main actors to play on? What will be the Israeli factor? Will Israel cooperate, or will Israel introduce obstacles?”

    The “big missing element,” Qarmout said, is “a political settlement or a political proposal to end this conflict.”

  • Return to menu

    Israeli President Isaac Herzog met Wednesday with the president of the International Red Cross, Mirjana Spoljaric, and her team, who were in Israel to prepare for a transfer of the hostages under a ceasefire and hostage release deal.

    Herzog emphasized the “utmost importance and sensitivity of this mission,” according to the president’s office.

    Following a pattern established in a hostage release in late 2023, the International Committee of the Red Cross would likely escort the hostages from an agreed assembly point along a secured route, a senior U.S. official said earlier Wednesday, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss the sensitive negotiations.

  • Return to menu

    Yehuda Cohen, whose son, Nimrod Cohen, is held hostage in Gaza, said the deal “is just the beginning.” There is still a “long way [and fight] to go,” he told The Post on Wednesday as news of the ceasefire deal broke.

    Nimrod was captured by Hamas-led fighters from his military base in southern Israel on Oct. 7, 2023. As a soldier, he would probably be released as part of the second phase, according to an Israeli official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss a sensitive matter, but the exact details would be set during the first phase.

    Cohen said he supports a deal, but he and other hostage families are frustrated that only some hostages will be released at first; they are fearful for those who will initially remain behind.

  • Ceasefire and hostage-release deal to halt Gaza war for now, after months of impasse

    Return to menu

    The first phase of the deal calls for a 42-day ceasefire and the release of an initial 33 hostages followed by subsequent releases during that period. A second senior U.S. official, who spoke on the condition on anonymity for the same reason, said three hostages would be released within 48 to 72 hours of the agreement, along with a still-unknown number of Palestinian prisoners being held in Israeli jails and an increased flow of humanitarian aid into Gaza.

  • Return to menu

    President Biden is expected to speak on the deal as soon as it announced in Qatar.

  • Monitoring the status of hostages still in Gaza

    Return to menu

    The cross-border attack that Hamas militants launched on Oct. 7, 2023, is regarded as the deadliest and most brutal attack in Israeli history. Palestinian militants shot, bombed and burned their way through Israeli towns, military posts and a music festival, killing and sometimes torturing 1,200 people — including more than 300 soldiers — and taking 251 more hostage, according to the Israeli government. We’re tracking what happened to each of them.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • A wounded Israeli soldier demands return of hostages, and war to go on

    Return to menu

    TEL AVIV — Yuval Shalem, 49, joined protests in Tel Aviv demanding a hostage deal for the first time Tuesday, while wounded and in a wheelchair.

    He was badly injured Saturday in an explosion that killed four fellow Israeli soldiers on patrol in Beit Hanoun, in the northern Gaza Strip, while looking for a tunnel entrance, he said. Shalem came to the protest, he added, to demand “both” — the return of the hostages and the war to go on.

  • Analysis: Trump moves the needle on a Gaza ceasefire

    Return to menu

    If a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas is clinched in the coming hours, the terms will likely be little different than what they would have been months ago. A number of living hostages in captivity in Gaza will be swapped for a number of Palestinian detainees in Israeli jails in a “first phase” of a truce. Hostilities will cease for a prescribed set of weeks, in the articulated hope that a later second phase of exchanges will happen and an extended peace will take root.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Blinken presents postwar plan for Gaza: Unite with West Bank under reformed Palestinian Authority

    Return to menu

    Secretary of State Antony Blinken presented a long-delayed plan for postwar Gaza on Tuesday that would unite the West Bank and Gaza under a reformed Palestinian Authority-led government.

    The plan would rely on the incoming Trump administration to carry it forward, reducing it to a Democratic proposal that can be readily dismissed or rewritten by a Republican White House.

  • Both sides hammering out final details, former Egyptian official says

    Return to menu

    JERUSALEM — Negotiators in Doha were still hammering out the final details of a ceasefire in Gaza on Tuesday, as momentum and expectations build that a 15-month war may soon halt and Israeli hostages will be freed in exchange for Palestinian prisoners.

    • Middle East conflict

    Israel and Hamas have agreed to a ceasefire deal — including the release of hostages — after more than 15 months of violence and tensions that have spilled over in the Middle East. Follow live updates on the ceasefire deal and the hostages remaining in Gaza.

    The Israel-Gaza war: On Oct. 7, 2023, Hamas militants launched an unprecedented cross-border attack on Israel, killing about 1,200 people and taking civilian hostages. Israel declared war on Hamas in response, launching a ground invasion that fueled the biggest displacement in the region since Israel’s creation in 1948. In July 2024, Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh was killed in an attack Hamas has blamed on Israel.

    Hezbollah: In late 2024, Israel and Lebanon’s Hezbollah agreed to a ceasefire deal, bringing a tenuous halt to more than a year of hostilities that included an Israeli invasion of southern Lebanon. Israel’s airstrikes into Lebanon had been intense and deadly, killing over 1,400 people including Hasan Nasrallah, Hezbollah’s longtime leader. The Israel-Lebanon border has a history of violence that dates back to Israel’s founding.

    Gaza crisis: In the Gaza Strip, Israel has waged one of this century’s most destructive wars, killing tens of thousands and plunging at least half of the population into “famine-like conditions.” For months, Israel has resisted pressure from Western allies to allow more humanitarian aid into the enclave.

    U.S. involvement: Despite tensions between Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and some U.S. politicians, including President Joe Biden, the United States supports Israel with weapons, funds aid packages, and has vetoed or abstained from the United Nations’ ceasefire resolutions.
